title: WJEC Welcome

moderator.name: Nico Drok, Chair, World Journalism Education Congress (WJEC) and Amanda Caldwell, Executive Director, Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication (AEJMC)

description: Join us for opening remarks and a warm welcome to the conference. This session will include general conference updates and information about the evening's Welcome Reception.

title: Journalism Education and Press Freedom
description: A paper presentation session covering various topics related to journalism education, press freedom, and the role of journalism in society.

title: Journalism in Uncertain Times
description: A paper presentation session discussing the challenges and transformations in journalism education amidst contemporary uncertainties.

panelists.name: Tom Felle
panelists.paper_title: Toward A Radical New Paradigm In Journalism Education: Enhancing Critical Thinking, Fact-Checking, and Al To Combat Disinformation

panelists.name: Barbara Gainey
panelists.paper_title: Extraordinary Threats Impact Traditional Journalism Education

panelists.name: Leli Bibilashvili
panelists.paper_title: Combating Fake News Through Education: The Georgian Experience

panelists.name: Natia Kaladze
panelists.paper_title: Combating Fake News Through Education: The Georgian Experience

panelists.paper_title: Cross-Cultural Misinformation Training: Reporting Results of A Novel U.S.-Mexico Partnership

panelists.paper_title: Cross-Cultural Misinformation Training: Reporting Results of A Novel U.S.-Mexico Partnership

panelists.name: Nuurrianti Jalli
panelists.paper_title: Cross-Cultural Misinformation Training: Reporting Results of A Novel U.S.-Mexico Partnership

panelists.paper_title: Cross-Cultural Misinformation Training: Reporting Results of A Novel U.S.-Mexico Partnership

panelists.name: Chris Boyington
panelists.paper_title: Cross-Cultural Misinformation Training: Reporting Results of A Novel U.S.-Mexico Partnership

panelists.name: Faith Frantz
panelists.paper_title: Cross-Cultural Misinformation Training: Reporting Results of A Novel U.S.-Mexico Partnership

title: Diversity, Equality and Inclusivity in a Diverse and Polarized World
description: In an era that the world and journalism are constantly changing, journalism education needs to provide multiple and diverse perspectives, offer a balance for journalism that happens around the clock and teach students the art of unbiased reporting. Only then will inclusive journalism effectively function as a tool for depolarization. Central Question: What are the most striking needs for journalism educators working with inclusive journalism in 2025?

panelists.name: Anne Leppäjärvi
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Nadia Vissers
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Teaching Trauma In Journalism Schools Across Cultures and Nations: Finding A Common Ground
description: This panel will bring scholars from different parts of the globe to offer recommendations for teaching mental health in journalism schools. Central Question: How Can Journalism Teachers Effectively Teach Mental Wellbeing In Their Classes?

panelists.name: Altaf Ullah Khan
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Carl Knauf
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Practicing Peace Journalism in the Current Political Climate
description: This panel will discuss the challenges of practicing peace journalism around the world and ways to overcome them. It will focus on examples of successful journalistic projects that implemented principles of peace journalism and brainstorm viable ideas for practicing peace journalism in politically charged environments. Central Question: How can individual journalists from democratic and non- democratic countries incorporate elements of peace journalism in their reporting?

panelists.name: Claudia Kozman
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Yulia Medvedeva
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Reimagining Journalism Education: The Role of University-led Student Reporting Programs
description: This syndicate will examine the evolving landscape of student reporting programs, highlighting key opportunities for journalism educators. It will also delve into the challenges educators face in launching and maintaining these programs. Central Question: What challenges do journalism educators face in implementing student reporting programs?

panelists.name: Sima Bhowmik
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Meg Little Riley
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Ready for Impact: How Engaged Media Research Can Help Build Strong Community-University Collaborations in Telling Local Stories
description: Academics, journalists, and community media practitioners will explore the links between new reporting models and collaborative and accessible communication research, and their impact on local communities. Central Question: If high-impact, engaged, university-based newsrooms, partnered with community- based media, are one key to preserve and advance the journalism profession, how can we grow those already in place, and how can we build more of them?

panelists.name: Mario Murillo
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Scott Brinton
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: GenAl Video Tools in News Video Production and Journalism Education
description: This syndicate will explore how journalism educators are integrating Al-powered video editing and production tools into their curriculum, the challenges they face in doing so, and where they draw the ethical boundaries for Al-generated video content. Central Question: How can journalism educators ethically and effectively integrate Al-powered video editing and production tools into their curriculum to prepare students for the evolving video journalism industry?

panelists.name: Debora Wenger
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Kris Vera-Phillips
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Community Trust, Media Literacy, and Informational Access
description: This syndicate explores creative approaches journalism educators; community media practitioners and civic organizers can take to teach students how to build trust with community members. It focuses on identifying best practices for promoting and protecting media literacy and public information access in fragmented and polarized social environments. Central Question: How can journalism educators, community media practitioners and civic organizers collaborate to develop and teach communication practices that build trust, promote media literacy and enhance informational access?

panelists.name: Antoine Haywood
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Andrea Wenzel
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Trauma Literacy, Education, and Research
description: A syndicate from the 2019 World Journalism Education Congress focused on gaps and opportunities regarding journalism and trauma education. The 2025 syndicate aims to determine gaps in journalism-related trauma pedagogy and provide recommendations focusing on trauma literacy. Central Question: What is the global status of teaching and training regarding journalism and trauma around the world?

panelists.name: Gretchen Dworznik Hoak
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Alexandra Wake
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Educating Journalism Students on Gender and Related Inequality Issues
description: This syndicate will build on and develop discussions at WJEC05 in Paris in 2019. The 2025 syndicate will consider progress over the past six years, while acknowledging new threats to this type of work. Central Question: What, if any, progress has been made over the past six years in educating journalism students globally on gender and related inequality issues?

panelists.name: Ingrid Bachmann
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Mia Moody
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Global Perspectives on Crisis and Disaster Journalism
description: This syndicate will provide global perspectives on natural disaster information and discuss the challenges as governments cut funding to science, scientists, and government agencies. Central Question: What are the local, national, and global implications of changes that influence news coverage and change access?

panelists.name: Mimi Perreault
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Grace Smith
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: News Influencers and Journalism Education: Rethinking Ethics and Pedagogy
description: This raises questions regarding how journalism education can help students to become ethical news influencers instead of abandoning that space to people without a journalistic orientation. Central Question: How do we frame and deliver journalism education to make it vital in the era of content creation and news influencers while holding on to journalism's core ethic?

panelists.name: Greg Munno
panelists.paper_title: Expert

panelists.name: Yayu Feng
panelists.paper_title: Rapporteur

title: Understanding the Changing Institutional Press
description: This panel brings together scholars who consider the institutional implications of emerging technological tools, journalistic reforms, and new, often globalized, investigative practices. The panel tackles these questions from a variety of disciplinary and international perspectives.

panelists.name: Rana Arafat
panelists.institution: City St George's University of London

title: Where Writing Fits in a Visual World
description: This panel will reconsider the writing curriculum in the face of new platforms and preferences. What kinds of writing should students focus on? What are the hallmarks of quality writing when it comes to different platforms? Where does Generative Al fit into learning the art and craft of writing?

panelists.name: Shelvia Dancy
panelists.institution: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

title: Teaching Journalism Students Statehouse and Public Affairs Reporting
description: With news desserts increasing across the US in rural and small communities, journalism students are increasingly covering local and state news for university-based news media.

title: Covering Sports in the Digital Age: Beyond the Scoreboard
description: This panel will explore how journalism programs can adapt their curricula to meet the evolving demands of sports media. Topics will include: multimedia storytelling & digital platforms, athlete access & player-controlled narratives; the intersection of sports and society; ethics in modern sports coverage.

title: WJEC-7 Ignite: Innovative Ideas for Teaching Journalism
description: Using the Ignite! motto “enlighten us, but make it quick,” educators with diverse backgrounds and perspectives present their most innovative teaching ideas at WJEC-7's Ignite Session. Following the traditional "Ignite" format, each presenter gets 5 minutes and 20 slides to share their successful classroom projects and exercises.

panelists.institution: City St. George's University of London
panelists.paper_title: Uncovering News in Data: Utilizing Al tools to Detect and Visualize Hidden Stories

panelists.paper_title: Motivating Students with Experiential Learning Using Sports Journalism Extracurricular Activity

title: Transparency, Trust and Tactics of Care: Teaching New(s) Methods for an Evolving Public
description: A plenary session featuring a keynote address by Tara Pixley, a visual journalist, producer, and professor, introduced by Judy Walgren.

title: What Journalism Should We Teach?": (Re) Imagining Journalism Pedagogy and Practice

moderator.name: Karen Fowler-Watt
moderator.institution: Dart Centre for Journalism and Trauma

description: This panel discussion is derived from contributions made to The Routledge Companion to Journalism Education. The panel discussion and audience interaction will focus on 3 key aspects of the question, "What journalism should we teach?": the challenging context of 'information disorder' and crisis of trust; navigating accusations of elitism and debates about inclusivity and diversity; and future directions in journalism education.

title: Educating Journalists to Counter Hate Speech: From Episodic Coverage to Active Resistance
description: This is the aim of a new UNESCO publication, Covering Hate Speech: A Guide for Journalists, which serves as the focal point of this panel. The panel highlights exemplary reportage from India and shows how collaborations with independent factchecking organizations and human rights monitors can help journalists carry out impactful counter-hate journalism despite resource constraints.

description: This is a closed meeting for outgoing, returning, and new members of the Elected Standing Committee on Teaching.

division: Broadcast and Mobile Journalism and Newspaper and Online News Divisions
title: Does X Still Mark the Spot? Teaching Aspiring Media Professionals How to Market Themselves in a World without #MediaTwitter
description: As we meet in the home of Meta, LinkedIn and, until recently, X, this panel will explore what role X plays in today's personal branding strategy for aspiring media professionals, as well as assignments and insights for using other social media platforms to help students achieve their career goals.

division: Minorities and Communication Division and Commission on the Status of Minorities
title: Joy as Resistance: Finding Happiness and Purpose in Academia When DEI is Under Fire
description: This panel includes faculty from a range of geographies who research, teach, and have the lived experience of the identities and concepts under fire. We draw from research on how communities have produced media as a form of mutual support and celebration in challenging times, and share our own experiences with finding purpose, joy, and solidarity as forms of resistance.

division: Scholastic Journalism Division and Internships and Careers Interest Group
title: High-Impact Learning: Alternative Assessment in Journalism and Mass Communication
description: No rubric captures the whole picture when it comes to student learning. Panel will discuss our research & experiences, propose implementation strategies, introduce assessment models and challenge preconceived notions about teaching & evaluation.

division: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer Interest Group and History Division
title: Queer Voices: Media's Role in Shaping San Francisco's LGBTQ+ Narrative
description: This panel examines the vital role of queer media in the queer rights movement in San Francisco, highlighting its connections to the national struggle for LGBTQ+ rights.

division: Small Programs Interest Group and Communication Theory and Methodology Division
title: Put This Another Way: Journalism Pedagogy in an Era of Media Mistrust
description: This panel will explore how faculty trained (or career experienced) in journalism and media have found new ways to bring practical journalism training into various educational models.

title: Helping Students Fill the Professional Gap

moderator.name: Mark Horvit
moderator.institution: Missouri, 2024 Scripps Howard Fund Teacher of the Year Recipient

description: Journalism programs around the country are deploying students to provide daily coverage of local and state governmental bodies, to do enterprise stories, and to tackle investigations and data-heavy projects. This panel will discuss what can be done to ensure students have the tools and knowledge to succeed.

division: Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication Elected Standing Committee on Professional Freedom and Responsibility
title: Spanish-Language Media Breakfast
description: The Thomas Jay Harris Institute for Hispanic & International Communication at Texas Tech University is pleased to sponsor this event bringing academics together with professionals working in Bay Area Spanish-language media to discuss current trends and how to prepare the next generation of workers for these media outlets. This session will be in English, starting at 9 a.m. Breakfast will be served to the first 75 attendees.
